content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy if you know the logic, hard otherwise.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfect level of complexity for a coding challenge if someone knows their regexes. A little hard otherwise. :-)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Nice Clash of Code, thanks for that.
Quite a fun clash of code. I also like that you can solve it without using regex so no one will be left behind.
Good idea, the statement is clear and the test cases seems comprehensive to me. ;)
It would be nice to have a comment saying that all tests will contain valid cases (or, otherwise, output "Invalid Case" if it's not a valid case).

Goal
* Please delete the extra "P" in "UPPPERFLATCASE".

* Consider rewriting the note as follows (I find "lack extra words" a bit confusing):

In this clash, any [[variable]] using a naming convention other than {{flatcase}} and {{UPPERFLATCASE}} always includes at least two words, which means it must contain a mix of letter cases, or include hyphens or underscores.

(Also, as the note won't appear in Reverse mode, players might indeed be worried about the exact thing as you described…)

Cases
* Please add cases of PascalCase variables where simple heuristics fail (e.g. checking only the first and last or first and second letters). Examples:

SavedToPC
LoadedHTML
URLParserA
APICallHandlerR
OSVersionXP
CGPlayersFR

(You might argue some of the variables might be capitalised differently, e.g. CgPlayersFr…)

(You could include something similar but in camelCase, though that shouldn't cause players the same degree of issues as PascalCase.)

Thanks.

Great feedback as always.

I've implemented all these changes, except I didn't want to do the first and second letter part because I feel like those are a bit abnormal, even if they are orthodox. Instead I did cases like "VariableA" where there are never two uppercase in a row, but first and last are uppercase.
I've added a constraint mentioning that now, and disabled Reverse, as I don't think it's good form to rely on leaving important information in the stub generator.

It's not definitely not hard, but I think it would take me about 3-4 minutes probably, which is good for a clash, imo. Plus, I suspect 95% of clashers would be able to solve it, which is nice for the newer coders.
